io.github.bananapuncher714.crafters.display

Class CraftDisplay

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.github.bananapuncher714.crafters.display.CraftDisplay
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Runnable

    public class CraftDisplay
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Runnable
    This is a per-inventory object, it manages all the 9 slots of a crafting table; Created on 2017-12-07
    Author:
    BananaPuncher714

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      CraftDisplay(PublicCraftingInventory inventory)
      Provide a PublicCraftingInventory, and the default height is used
      CraftDisplay(PublicCraftingInventory inventory, double itemHeight)
      Same as CraftDisplay(PublicCraftingInventory), but now you can provide the height of the items

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void forceUpdate()
      This forces an update immediately, without delay and forcefully.
      PublicCraftingInventory getInventory() 
      java.util.List<ItemDisplay> getItemDisplays() 
      org.bukkit.Location getLocation() 
      void run()
      You shouldn't run this directly, use the update() method instead
      void stop()
      Simply stops each of the 9 ItemDisplays this is responsible for
      void update()
      All this really does is run the run() method some ticks after this is called
      void update(int col, int row)
      This is the passive update method; see update(int, int, boolean)
      void update(int col, int row, boolean force)
      Don't call this from the ItemDisplayCreateEvent or the ItemDisplayDestroyEvent, as it will cause a stackOverflowException;

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        equals, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • CraftDisplay

        public CraftDisplay(PublicCraftingInventory inventory)
        Provide a PublicCraftingInventory, and the default height is used
        Parameters:
        inventory - It must be a PublicCraftingInventory, NOT your normal Bukkit inventory

      • CraftDisplay

        public CraftDisplay(PublicCraftingInventory inventory,
                    double itemHeight)
        Same as CraftDisplay(PublicCraftingInventory), but now you can provide the height of the items
        Parameters:
        inventory - Your PublicCraftingInventory instance
        itemHeight - The height of the item that will be displayed above the table

    • Method Detail

      • update

        public void update()
        All this really does is run the run() method some ticks after this is called

      • forceUpdate

        public void forceUpdate()
        This forces an update immediately, without delay and forcefully.

      • update

        public void update(int col,
                   int row)
        This is the passive update method; see update(int, int, boolean)
        Parameters:
        col - The columns of a workbench, from left to right, counting 0 to 2
        row - The rows of a workbench, from top to bottom, counting 0 to 2

      • update

        public void update(int col,
                   int row,
                   boolean force)
        Don't call this from the ItemDisplayCreateEvent or the ItemDisplayDestroyEvent, as it will cause a stackOverflowException;
        Parameters:
        col - The columns of a workbench, from left to right, counting 0 to 2
        row - The rows of a workbench, from top to bottom, counting 0 to 2
        force - Whether or not to force an update if the items in the current slot are similar

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Simply stops each of the 9 ItemDisplays this is responsible for

      • getInventory

        public PublicCraftingInventory getInventory()

      • getItemDisplays

        public java.util.List<ItemDisplay> getItemDisplays()

      • getLocation

        public org.bukkit.Location getLocation()

      • run

        public void run()
        You shouldn't run this directly, use the update() method instead
        Specified by:
        run in interface java.lang.Runnable
